{{Infobox website |name = Lighthouse Labs |logo = |company_type = [[Coding Bootcamp]] |foundation = 2013 |location_city = |locations = {{flagicon|Canada}} [[Vancouver]], [[Toronto]], [[Calgary]], [[Montreal]], [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]], [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]], [[Ottawa]] |area_served = |key_people = |industry = [[Education]] |products = |operating_income = |net_income = |owner = |num_employees = |parent = |divisions = |subsid = |url = {{URL|http://www.lighthouselabs.ca}} |ipv6 = |website_type = |advertising = |num_users = |language = |registration = |launch_date = |current_status = |commercial? = |screenshot = |caption = Lighthouse Labs Current Logo }} '''Lighthouse Labs''' is a [[coding bootcamp]] for [[web development|web]] and mobile software development in multiple cities across [[Canada]]. The establishment organizes an annual free learn-to-code event, [[The HTML500]], in partnership with [[Telus]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2015/01/26/html500-vancouver_n_6542302.html|title=The HTML500 Bootcamp Teaches Free Coding To Promote Digital Literacy|date= 25 Jan 2015|website=huffingtonpost.ca}}</ref> More recently, the bootcamp became the first organization to offer a remote-hybrid [[web development]] program in [[Whitehorse, Yukon|Whitehorse]] through a partnership with the Government of [[Yukon]].<ref name="gov.yk.ca">{{cite web |url=http://www.gov.yk.ca/news/15-189.html#.VXc4E1xVhHw|title=Coding boot camp trains future Yukon web developers|date= 27 May 2015|website=gov.yk.ca/}}</ref>
==Locations==
===Vancouver=== Opened in 2013, Lighthouse Labs' first immersive bootcamp facility is based out of Launch Academy, an [[Business Incubator|incubator]] in the heart of the city's [[Gastown]] neighborhood.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://betakit.com/new-vancouver-based-coding-academy-lighthouse-labs-to-launch-this-fall/ |title=New Vancouver-Based Coding Academy to launch this fall|author=Joseph Czikk |date= 3 September 2013|website=betakit.com}}</ref> Students learn front and back-end development through the bootcamp's Web and iOS programs.<ref name="VanCity Buzz">{{cite web|url=http://www.vancitybuzz.com/2015/04/lighthouse-labs-vancouver-coding-bootcamp/|title=A new coding bootcamp is filling the talent gap in Vancouver|accessdate=2015-06-11}}</ref> The iOS program, launched in July 2014, is arguably Canada's first immersive iOS immersive program.<ref name="Tech Vibes">{{cite web|url=http://www.techvibes.com/blog/lighthouse-labs-launches-ios-bootcamp-2014-04-14|title=Vancouver's Lighthouse Labs Launches Canada's First iOS Bootcamp Course|accessdate=2015-06-11}}</ref>
===Toronto=== As part of a national partnership with Highline, a seed stage investment platform, Lighthouse Labs announced the launch of its Toronto operations during [[The HTML500]] in February 2015.<ref name="Toronto Is Awesome">{{cite web|url=http://www.torontoisawesome.com/lifestyle/torontos-newest-tech-bootcamp-will-change-your-career-forever/ |title=Toronto’s Newest Tech Bootcamp Will Change Your Career Forever |accessdate=2015-06-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150516161031/http://www.torontoisawesome.com/lifestyle/torontos-newest-tech-bootcamp-will-change-your-career-forever |archivedate=2015-05-16 |df= }}</ref> Located in Highline's office in downtown Toronto, the facility offers enrollment in any of the bootcamp's full-time or part-time programs. It joins existing Toronto-based bootcamps such as Bitmaker Labs, BrainStation, HackerYou, and Red Academy as one of several developer bootcamps that offer in-person learning opportunities to individuals in the [[Greater Toronto Area]].<ref name="HackerYou">{{cite web|url=http://hackeryou.com/learn-to-code-in-2015-a-list-of-torontos-in-person-learning-opportunities/|title=Learn to Code in 2015: A List of Toronto’s In-Person Learning Opportunities|accessdate=2015-06-11}}</ref>
===Calgary=== In April 2015, Lighthouse Labs launched a 'pop-up' program in Calgary through its national partnership with Highline, a co-venture platform that helps early stage digital startups. Lighthouse Labs in Calgary currently offers students the opportunity to enroll in a 6-week part-time program focused primarily on learning the fundamentals of web development.<ref name="HIGHLINE">{{cite web|url=http://www.highline.vc/articles/highline-lighthouse-labs/|title=National Partnership with Highline|accessdate=2015-06-10}}</ref><ref name="Lighthouse Labs Calgary">{{cite web|url=https://lighthouselabs.ca/calgary|title=Lighthouse Labs Calgary|accessdate=2015-06-10}}</ref>
===Whitehorse=== In partnership with the Government of [[Yukon]], Lighthouse Labs launched the territory's first web development bootcamp via a remote-hybrid program.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/yukoners-brave-intense-eight-week-coding-camp-1.3088670 |title=Yukoners brave intense eight-week 'coding camp'|date= 25 Feb 2015|website=cbc.ca}}</ref> Students remotely attend lectures from the bootcamp's Vancouver location and have access to on-site assistance through Mentors in the facility <ref name="gov.yk.ca"/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.biv.com/article/2015/5/hybrid-coding-boot-camp-aims-bring-global-tech-sec/|title=‘Hybrid’ coding boot camp aims to bring tech sector to rural Canada|date= 4 May 2015|website=www.biv.com}}</ref>
== Scholarships ==
=== Simon Fraser University === The 'Lighthouse Labs Prize' is an annual scholarship open to students of [[Simon Fraser University]]'s [[The Faculty of Communication, Art and Technology at Simon Fraser University|Faculty of Communication, Art & Technology]]. Worth over $7000, the scholarship awards one student a spot in the bootcamp's web-development program in Vancouver and is currently in its second year of institution.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sfu.ca/fcat/blog/spring-2015/lighthouse-labs-prize-.html|title=Apply Today to Earn a Spot in Lighthouse Labs Web Development Bootcamp|date=2015-06-10}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Coursera]] * [[The Data Incubator]] * [[Codecademy]] * [[Khan Academy]] * [[General Assembly]] * [[Lynda.com]] * [[App Academy]] * [[Bloc (code school)]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.lighthouselabs.ca Lighthouse Labs website]

In [[music cognition]] and [[musical analysis]], the study of '''melodic expectation''' considers the engagement of the brain's predictive mechanisms in response to music.<ref name="Margulis2007"/> For example, if the ascending musical partial [[octave]] "do-re-mi-fa-sol-la-ti-..." is heard, listeners familiar with Western music will have a strong expectation to hear or provide one more note, "do", to complete the octave.
Melodic expectation can be considered at the [[Esthesic and poietic|esthesic level]],<ref name="Nattiez1990">{{cite book |author=Jean-Jacques Nattiez | publisher =Princeton University Press |date= 1992 |title=Music and Discourse: Toward a Semiology of Music (Musicologie générale et sémiologie), translated by Carolyn Abbate | isbn=978-0-691-02714-2}}</ref> in which case the focus lies on the listener and its response to music.<ref name="Margulis2007"/> It can be considered at the [[neutral level]],<ref name="Nattiez1990"/> in which case the focus switches to the actual musical content, such as the "printed notes themselves".<ref name="EN1992"/> At the neutral level, the observer may consider logical implications projected onto future elements by past elements<ref name="EN1990"/><ref name = "SC5"/> or derive statistical observations from [[information theory]].<ref name="Youngblood1958"/>
==A multifaceted concept==
The notion of melodic expectation has prompted the existence of a corpus of studies in which authors often choose to provide their own terminology in place of using the literature's.<ref name = "SC5"/> This results in an important number of different terms that all point towards the phenomenon of musical expectation:<ref name = "SC5"/><ref name="MMF2006">{{cite web |author=Morwaread M. Farbood | publisher = Massachusetts Institute of Technology |date=2006 | url=http://www.al-edu.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/MaryFarbood-A-Quantitative-Parametric-Model-of-Musical-Tension-PhD-Thesis-2006.pdf |title=A quantitative, parametric model of musical tension, submitted to the Program in Media Arts and Sciences, School of Architecture and Planning, in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Tod Machover, supervisor) | accessdate=2014-11-12}}</ref>
* Anticipation.<ref name="Levy2003">{{cite web |author= Fabien Lévy| publisher = Ecole des Hautes Etudes en Sciences Sociales |date=2004 | url=http://recherche.ircam.fr/equipes/repmus/Rapports/TheseFabLevy.pdf |title= Complexité grammatologique et complexité aperceptive en musique, submitted in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy at the EHESS (Jean-Marc Chouvel, Marc Chemillier, directors) | accessdate=2014-11-11 |language=French}}</ref><ref name="Thompson2007">{{cite web |author=William F. Thompson | publisher = Empirical Musicology Review, II/2| date=2007 | url=http://asage.org/index.php/ASAGE/article/viewFile/137/66 |title= David Huron, Sweet anticipation: music and the psychology of expectation | accessdate=2014-11-11|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name="Huron2006"/> * Arousal.<ref name="Meyer1957">{{cite journal |author= Leonard B. Meyer | publisher = Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism, XV/4|date=1957 |title=Meaning in music and information theory | jstor = 427154}}</ref> * Deduction.<ref name="EN2000" /> * Directionality.<ref name="Arlettaz2000">{{cite book |author= Vincent Arlettaz | publisher = Sprimont, Pierre Mardaga Editeur |date= 2000 |title= Musica Ficta, une histoire des sensibles du XIIIe au XVIe siècle |isbn=978-2870097274|language=French}}</ref><ref name="Lester2002">{{cite book |author= Joel Lester | publisher = Cambridge University Press |date= 2002 |title= Rameau and eighteenth-century harmonic theory, The Cambridge History of Western Music Theory, directed by Thomas Christensen |isbn=9780521686983}}</ref><ref name="EHM2005"/> * Expectancy, expectation, expectedness, and in French ''attente''.<ref name="Margulis2007">{{cite journal |author= Elizabeth H. Margulis |date= 2007| url=http://mts.oxfordjournals.org/content/29/2/197.short |title=Surprise and Listening Ahead: Analytical Engagements with Musical Tendencies | journal = Music Theory Spectrum|volume= 29 |issue= 2|pages= 197–217| accessdate=2014-11-11|subscription=yes| doi = 10.1525/mts.2007.29.2.197}}</ref><ref name="MMF2006"/><ref name="Levy2003"/><ref name="Thompson2007"/><ref name="Abdallah2009">{{cite journal |author1=Samer Abdallah |author2=Mark Plumbley |lastauthoramp=yes |date=2009 | url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09540090902733756#.VGFvl_SG-R0 |title=Information dynamics: patterns of expectation and surprise in the perception of music | accessdate=2014-11-11|subscription=yes | doi=10.1080/09540090902733756 | volume=21 |issue=2–3 | journal=Connection Science | pages=89–117}}</ref><ref name="Aiello2007">{{cite web |author=Rita Aiello | publisher = Empirical Musicology Review, II/2 |date=2007 | url=http://asage.org/index.php/ASAGE/article/viewFile/137/66 |title= David Huron, Sweet anticipation: music and the psychology of expectation| accessdate=2014-11-11|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name ="Bharucha1993">{{cite book |author=Jamshed J. Bharucha | publisher =Oxford University Press |date=1993 |title= Tonality and Expectation, in Musical Perceptions pp. 213-239, edited by Rita Aiello | isbn=9780195064766}}</ref><ref name="Bharucha1987"/><ref name="Carlsen1981">{{cite web |author=James C. Carlsen | publisher =Psychomusicology, I|date=1981 | url=http://psycnet.apa.org/journals/pmu/1/1/12/ |title=Some factors which influence melodic expectancy | accessdate=2014-11-11|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name="Cuddy1995">{{cite journal |author1=Lola Cuddy |author2=Carole Lunney |lastauthoramp=yes |date=1995 |title=Expectancies Generated by Melodic Intervals: Perceptual Judgments of Melodic Continuity |journal=Perception & Psychophysics |volume=57 |issue=4 |pages=451–462 |doi=10.3758/BF03213071 }}</ref><ref name="Schmukler1989">{{cite journal |author=Mark A. Schmukler | publisher =Music Perception, VII |date=1989 |title=Expectation in music: Investigation of melodic and harmonic processes | jstor =40285454 }}</ref><ref name="Sadai1986">{{cite journal |author= Yizhak Sadaï| publisher = International Review of the Aesthetics and Sociology of Music, XVII/2|date=1986 |title= Les aspects systémiques et énigmatiques de la musique tonale, points d'appui et points d'interrogation |language=French| jstor = 836671}}</ref><ref name="EGS1996"/><ref name="EGS1997"/> * Facilitation.<ref name="Levy2003"/><ref name="EHM2005"/><ref name="Bharucha1987">{{cite journal |author= Jamshed J. Bharucha | publisher =Music Perception: An Interdisciplinary Journal, V/1 |date=1987 |title=Music Cognition and Perceptual Facilitation: A Connectionist Framework | jstor =40285384 }}</ref> * Implication / realization.<ref name="MMF2006"/><ref name="Thompson2007"/><ref name="EN2000" /><ref name="EHM2005"/><ref name="Cumming1992">{{cite journal |author=Naomi Cumming |date=1992 |title=Eugene Narmour's Theory of Melody | jstor = 854031}}</ref><ref name="Snyder2001">{{cite book |author=Bob Snyder | publisher =M.I.T Press |date=2001 |title= Music and Memory|isbn=9780262692373}}</ref> * Implication (independent from realization).<ref name="Meyer1957"/><ref name="Bharucha1987"/> * Induction.<ref name="Levy2003"/><ref name="Thompson2007"/><ref name="EN2000" /> * Inertia.<ref name="Thompson2007"/><ref name="Aiello2007"/><ref name="Larson2005">{{cite journal |author1=Steve Larson |author2=Leigh Vanhandel |lastauthoramp=yes | date=2005 |title=Measuring musical forces |journal=Music Perception |volume=23 |issue=2 |pages=119–136 |doi=10.1525/mp.2005.23.2.119 }}</ref> * Musical force(s).<ref name="Larson2005"/> * Previsibility, predictibility and prediction.<ref name="Youngblood1958">{{cite journal |author=Joseph E. Youngblood | publisher = Journal of Music Theory, II/1 |date=1958 |title=Style as information | jstor = 842928 }}</ref><ref name="Levy2003"/><ref name="Thompson2007"/><ref name="Meyer1957"/><ref name="Aiello2007"/><ref name="Hiller1967">{{cite journal |author1=Lejaren Hiller |author2=Ramon Fuller |lastauthoramp=yes | publisher =Journal of Music Theory, XI/1 |date=1967 |title= Structure and Information in Webern's Symphonie, Op. 21 |jstor=842949 }}</ref><ref name="Knopoff1981">{{cite journal |author=Leon Knopoff et William Hutchinson | publisher =Journal of Music Theory, 25th Anniversary Issue, XXV/1 |date=1981 |title=Information theory for music continua | jstor =843465 }}</ref><ref name="Margulis2008">{{cite journal |author=Elizabeth H. Margulis et Andrew P. Beatty |title=Musical style, psychoaesthetics, and prospects for entropy as an analytic tool | journal = Computer Music Journal |volume=32 |issue=4 |pages=64–78 | doi = 10.1162/comj.2008.32.4.64 | year = 2008 }}</ref><ref name="Snyder1990">{{cite journal |author=John L. Snyder | publisher = Music Theory Spectrum, XII/1 |date=1990 |title=Entropy as a measure of musical style: the influence of a priori assumptions | jstor = 746148 }}</ref> * Resolution.<ref name="MMF2006"/><ref name="Arlettaz2000"/><ref name="EHM2005"/><ref name="Bharucha1987"/><ref name="Sadai1986"/><ref name="Cumming1992"/><ref name="RushtonGrove">{{cite web |author=Julie Rushton | publisher = Grove Music Online |title=Resolution |url=http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/23234 | accessdate=2013-07-01|subscription=yes}}</ref> * Tension / release, tension / relaxation.<ref name="MMF2006"/><ref name="Thompson2007"/><ref name="Aiello2007"/><ref name="GTTM"/> * Closure, which may be used as the ending of the expectation process,<ref name="Margulis2007"/><ref name="Agawu1992">{{cite journal |author= Kofi Agawu| publisher = Music Analysis, XI/1 |date=1992 |title=Theory and Practice in the Analysis of the Nineteenth-Century Lied | jstor = 854301 }}</ref> as a group boundary,<ref name="Snyder2001"/> or as both simultaneously.<ref name="GTTM"/>
Expectation can also be found mentioned in relation to concepts originating from the field of [[information theory]] such as [[entropy]].<ref name="Youngblood1958"/><ref name="Levy2003"/><ref name="Meyer1957"/><ref name="Abdallah2009"/><ref name="Hiller1967"/><ref name="Knopoff1981"/><ref name="Margulis2008"/><ref name="Snyder1990"/> Hybridization of information theory and humanities results in the birth of yet other notions, particularly variations upon the notion of entropy modified for the need of description of musical content.<ref name="Culpepper2010">{{cite web |author=Sarah E. Culpepper | publisher =The University of Iowa |date= | url=http://ir.uiowa.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1844&context=etd |title= Musical time and information theory entropy, submitted in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the Master of Arts degree in Music in the Graduate College of The University of Iowa| accessdate=2014-11-11}}</ref>
Consideration of musical expectation can be sorted into four trends.<ref name = "SC5"/>
* A first trend may include publications written in the 1950s by Meyer, Younblood and Krahenbuehl & Coons that are concerned with objectivization and rationalization of the concepts of arousal, uncertainty, or non-confirmation of a prediction using information theory.<ref name="Youngblood1958"/><ref name="Meyer1957"/><ref name="Krahenbuehl1959">{{cite journal |author1=David Krahenbuehl |author2=Edgar Coons |lastauthoramp=yes | publisher =Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism, XVII/4 |date=1959 |title= Information as a measure of experience in music|jstor=428224 }}</ref> * A second trend may concern the more recent publications that include a step-by-step music analysis process at the neutral level, such as the [[generative theory of tonal music]]<ref name="GTTM"/> and Narmour's [[Implication-Realization]] model.<ref name="EN1992"/><ref name="EN1990"/> * A third trend may provide quantitative models based on computer algorithms, such as Margulis' model of melodic expectation or Farbood's model of musical tension.<ref name="MMF2006"/><ref name="EHM2005"/> * A fourth trend may group generalist theories whose focus lies neither in step-by-step processes nor in quantitative operations, and may include elements pertinent to the esthesic level such as cognition and neurophysiology. This includes Larson's "musical forces"<ref name="Larson2005"/> and Huron's theory of general expectation.<ref name="Huron2006">{{cite book |author=David Huron | publisher =M.I.T. Press |date=2006 |title=Sweet anticipation: music and the psychology of expectation | isbn= 9780262582780}}</ref>
== Leonard Meyer ==
[[Leonard B. Meyer|Leonard Meyer]]'s ''Emotion and Meaning in Music''<ref name="Meyer">{{cite book|author=Leonard B. Meyer | publisher = Chicago University Press |date=1956 | title= Emotion and Meaning in Music |isbn=978-0-226-52139-8}}</ref> is the classic text in music expectation.{{Citation needed|date=November 2014}} Meyer's starting point is the belief that the experience of music (as a listener) is derived from one's emotions and feelings about the music, which themselves are a function of relationships within the music itself. Meyer writes that listeners bring with them a vast body of musical experiences that, as one listens to a piece, conditions one's response to that piece as it unfolds. Meyer argued that music's evocative power derives from its capacity to generate, suspend, prolongate, or violate these expectations.
Meyer models listener expectation in two levels. On a perceptual level, Meyer draws on [[Gestalt psychology]] to explain how listeners build mental representations of auditory phenomena. Above this raw perceptual level, Meyer argues that learning shapes (and re-shapes) one's expectations over time.
== Generative Theory of Tonal Music (GTTM) == {{main|generative theory of tonal music}}
== Implication-Realization model == {{main|Implication-Realization}} Narmour's (1992) Implication-Realization (I-R) Model is a detailed formalization based on Meyer's work on expectation.{{Citation needed|date=November 2014}} A fundamental difference between Narmour's models and most theories of expectation lies in the author's conviction according to which a genuine theory should be formulated in falsifiable terms. According to Narmour, prior knowledge of musical expectation is based too heavily upon percepts, introspection and internalization, which bring insoluble epistemological problems.<ref name="EN1992"/> The theory focuses on how ''implicative intervals'' set up expectations for certain ''realizations'' to follow. The [[Implication-Realization|I-R]] model includes two primary factors: proximity and direction.<ref name="EN1992"/><ref name="EN1990"/><ref name="EGS1996">{{cite journal|author=E. Glenn Schellenberg |date=1996 | title= Expectancy in melody: tests of the implication-realization model |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0010027795006656|subscription=yes |doi=10.1016/0010-0277(95)00665-6 |pmid=8808327 |volume=58 |issue=1 |journal=Cognition |pages=75–125}}</ref><ref name="EGS1997">{{cite journal|author=E. Glenn Schellenberg | publisher = Music Perception: An Interdisciplinary Journal, XIV/3 |date=1997 | title= Simplifying the Implication-Realization Model of Melodic Expectancy | jstor = 40285723 }}</ref> [[Fred Lerdahl|Lerdahl]] extended the system by developing a tonal [[pitch space]] and adding a stability factor (based on [[Generative theory of tonal music|Lerdahl's prior work]]) and a mobility factor.<ref name="FL2001">{{cite book|author=Fred Lerdahl | publisher = Oxford University Press |date=2001 | title= Tonal Pitch Space |isbn= 978-0-19-505834-5}}</ref>
== Bimbot and al.'s System & Contrast model ==
Mainly developed at [http://www.irisa.fr/en/ IRISA] since 2011 by Frédéric Bimbot and Emmanuel Deruty, the system & contrast or S&C model of implication<ref name="SC5">{{cite web |author1=Emmanuel Deruty, Frédéric Bimbot |author2=Brigitte van Wymeersch |lastauthoramp=yes | publisher = INRIA/Université Catholique de Louvain |date=2013 | url=https://hal.inria.fr/hal-00965914 |title=Methodological and musicological investigation of the System & Contrast model for musical form description |accessdate=2014-11-09}}</ref><ref name="SC1">{{cite web |author1=Frédéric Bimbot |author2=Emmanuel Deruty |author3=Gabriel Sargent |author4=Emmanuel Vincent | publisher = INRIA |date=2012 | url=http://hal.inria.fr/hal-00868398 |title= System & Contrast: A Polymorphous Model Of The Inner Organization Of Structural Segments Within Music Pieces |pages=40 |accessdate=2014-11-09}}</ref><ref name="SC2">{{cite web |author1=Frédéric Bimbot |author2=Emmanuel Deruty |author3=Gabriel Sargent |author4=Emmanuel Vincent | publisher = INRIA |date=June 2012 | url=https://hal.inria.fr/hal-00713196 |title= Complementary report to the Article "Semiotic structure labeling of music pieces: concepts, methods and annotation conventions" (Proceedings ISMIR 2012) |accessdate=2014-11-09}}</ref><ref name="SC3">{{cite web |author1=Frédéric Bimbot |author2=Emmanuel Deruty |author3=Gabriel Sargent |author4=Emmanuel Vincent | publisher = ISMIR |date= October 2012 | url=http://ismir2012.ismir.net/event/papers/235_ISMIR_2012.pdf |title=Semiotic structure labeling of music pieces: concepts, methods and annotation conventions |accessdate=2014-11-09}}</ref><ref name="SC4">{{cite web |author= Frédéric Bimbot, Gabriel Sargent, Emmanuel Deruty Corentin Guichaoua and Emmanuel Vincent| publisher = AES |date=January 2014 | url=http://www.aes.org/e-lib/browse.cfm?elib=17115 |title=Semiotic Description Of Music Structure : An Introduction To The Quaero/Metiss Structural Annotations |accessdate=2014-11-09|subscription=yes}}</ref> derives from the two fundamental hypotheses underlying the I-R model.<ref name="EN1990">{{cite book|author=Eugene Narmour | publisher = University of Chicago Press |date=1990 | title= The Analysis and Cognition of Basic Melodic Structures: The Implication-Realization Model|isbn=978-0-226-56845-4}}</ref> It is rooted in Narmour's conviction according to which any model of expectation should be expressed in logical, falsifiable terms.<ref name="EN1992">{{cite book|author=Eugene Narmour | publisher = University of Chicago Press |date=1992 | title= The Analysis and Cognition of Melodic Complexity: the Implication-Realization model|isbn=978-0-226-56842-3}}</ref> It operates at the neutral level and differs from the I-R model in several regards:
* while Narmour's two fundamental hypotheses address the relations between three elements,<ref name="EN1990"/> the fundamental hypotheses leading to the S&C model address the relations between four elements. Therefore, it can be considered as more directly suited to the classical ''sentence'' and ''period'' forms,<ref name="Caplin">{{cite book|author=William E. Caplin | publisher = Oxford University Press |date=1998 | title= Classical Form: A Theory of Formal Functions for the Instrumental Music of Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven |isbn=978-0195143997}}</ref> as well as to popular music forms;<ref name = "SC5"/><ref name="SC2"/> * while Narmour's I-R model addresses one-dimensional relations,<ref name = "SC5"/><ref name="EN2000">{{cite journal|author=Eugene Narmour | publisher = Music Perception, XVII/3 |date=2000 | title= Music expectation by cognitive rule-mapping | jstor = 40285821 }}</ref> the S&C model includes relations on two potentially independent dimensions; * the S&C model may encompass all aspects of the musical language, not only the melodic structure.<ref name="SC5"/><ref name="SC1"/><ref name="SC2"/><ref name="SC3"/><ref name="SC4"/>
== Margulis's model of melodic expectation ==
Margulis's 2005 model<ref name="EHM2005">{{cite journal|author=Elizabeth H. Margulis |date=2005 | title= A model of melodic expectation | journal = Music Perception: An Interdisciplinary Journal |volume=22 |issue=4 |pages=663–714 | doi = 10.1525/mp.2005.22.4.663 }}</ref> further extends the I-R model. First, Margulis added a melodic attraction factor, from some of Lerdahl's work. Second, while the I-R model relies on a single (local) interval to establish an implication (an expectation), Margulis attempts to model intervalic (local) expectation as well as more deeply schematic (global) expectation. For this, Margulis relies on Lerdahl's and Jackendoff's GTTM<ref name="GTTM">{{cite book|author1=Fred Lerdhal |author2=Ray Jackendoff |lastauthoramp=yes | publisher = MIT Press |date=1983 | title= A Generative Theory of Tonal Music |isbn=978-0-262-62107-6}}</ref> to provide a time-span reduction. At each hierarchical level (a different time scale) in the reduction, Margulis applies her model. These separate levels of analysis are combined through averaging, with each level weighted according to values derived from the time-span reduction. Finally, Margulis's model is explicit and realizable, and yields quantitative output. The output - melodic expectation at each time instant - is a single function of time.
Margulis's model describes three distinct types of listener reactions, each derived from listener-experienced ''tension'': *Surprise-Tension: inversely proportional to degree of expectancy; results in intensity or dynamism. *Denial-Tension: proportional to the discrepancy between the expectancy of the most expected event and the expectancy of the actually perceived event; results in desire, drive, will. *Expectancy-Tension: proportional to the degree of expectancy of the most expected event (in other words, if the listener had no idea what to expect next, the expectancy-tension would be low); results in strain or yearning.<ref name="MMF2006"/>

[[File:Socrates Pio-Clementino Inv314.jpg|right|thumb|150px|[[Socrates]] (depicted in this bust) justified the use of noble lies in [[Plato]]'s ''[[Republic (Plato)|Republic]]''.<ref>Aruffo, Madeline. [https://www.bu.edu/av/core/journal/xxiii/Aruffo.pdf "Problems with the Noble Lie."] ''Boston University''. Accessed 4 December 2017.</ref>]] In [[politics]], a '''noble lie''' is a [[myth]] or [[Lie|untruth]], often, but not invariably, of a religious nature, knowingly propagated by an [[elite]] to maintain social harmony or to advance an agenda. The noble lie is a concept originated by [[Plato]] as described in the ''[[The Republic (Plato)|Republic]]''.
In [[religion]], a '''pious fiction''' is a narrative that is presented as true by the author, but is considered by others to be fictional albeit produced with an altruistic motivation. The term is sometimes used [[pejorative]]ly to suggest that the author of the narrative was deliberately misleading readers for selfish or deceitful reasons. The term is often used in religious contexts, sometimes referring to passages in religious texts.
==Plato's ''Republic''== [[File:P. Oxy. LII 3679.jpg|thumb|P. Oxy. 3679, manuscript from the 3rd century AD, containing fragments of Plato's Republic.]] {{main|The Republic (Plato)}} Plato presented the Noble Lie (γενναῖον ψεῦδος, ''gennaion pseudos'' – literally, "a lie or wrong opinion about origin") in the fictional tale known as the myth or parable of the metals. In it, Socrates provides the origin of the three [[social class]]es who compose the republic proposed by Plato; Socrates speaks of a [[Social stratification|socially stratified society]], wherein the populace are told "a sort of Phoenician tale":
{{Quotation|...the earth, as being their mother, delivered them, and now, as if their land were their mother and their nurse, they ought to take thought for her and defend her against any attack, and regard the other citizens as their brothers and children of the self-same earth...While all of you, in the city, are brothers, we will say in our tale, yet god, in fashioning those of you who are fitted to hold rule, mingled gold in their generation, for which reason they are the most precious—but in the helpers, silver, and iron and brass in the farmers and other craftsmen. And, as you are all akin, though for the most part you will breed after your kinds, it may sometimes happen that a golden father would beget a silver son, and that a golden offspring would come from a silver sire, and that the rest would, in like manner, be born of one another. So that the first and chief injunction that the god lays upon the rulers is that of nothing else are they to be such careful guardians, and so intently observant as of the intermixture of these metals in the souls of their offspring, and if sons are born to them with an infusion of brass or iron they shall by no means give way to pity in their treatment of them, but shall assign to each the status due to his nature and thrust them out among the artisans or the farmers. And again, if from these there is born a son with unexpected gold or silver in his composition they shall honor such and bid them go up higher, some to the office of guardian, some to the assistanceship, alleging that there is an oracle that the city shall then be overthrown when the man of iron or brass is its guardian.<ref>Book 3, 414e–15c</ref>}}
Socrates proposes and claims that if the people believed "this myth...[it] would have a good effect, making them more inclined to care for the state and one another."<ref>Book 3, 415c–d</ref> This is his ''noble lie'': "a contrivance for one of those falsehoods that come into being in case of need, of which we were just now talking, some noble one..."<ref>414b–c</ref>
==Modern views==
===Karl Popper=== [[File:Karl Popper2.jpg|right|thumb|Sir Karl Popper in 1990]] {{main article|Karl Popper}} Karl Popper accused Plato of trying to base religion on a noble lie as well. In ''[[The Open Society and Its Enemies]]'', Popper remarks, "It is hard to understand why those of Plato's commentators who praise him for fighting against the subversive conventionalism of the Sophists, and for establishing a spiritual naturalism ultimately based on religion, fail to censure him for making a convention, or rather an invention, the ultimate basis of religion." Religion for Plato is a noble lie, at least if we assume that Plato meant all of this sincerely, not cynically. Popper finds Plato's conception of religion to have been very influential in subsequent thought.<ref name="popper">[https://web.archive.org/web/20071209060939/http://www.positiveliberty.com/2007/07/open-society-vi-on-religion-as-a-noble-lie.html Positive Liberty » Open Society VI: On Religion as a Noble Lie<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Leo Strauss===
{{main article|Leo Strauss}} Strauss noted that thinkers of the first rank, going back to Plato, had raised the problem of whether good and effective politicians could be completely truthful and still achieve the necessary ends of their society. By implication, Strauss asks his readers to consider whether it is true that noble lies have no role at all to play in uniting and guiding the [[polis]]. Are myths needed to give people meaning and purpose and to ensure a stable society? Or can men dedicated to relentlessly examining, in [[Nietzsche]]'s language, those "deadly truths," flourish freely? Thus, is there a limit to the political, and what can be known absolutely? In ''The City and Man,'' Strauss discusses the myths outlined in [[The Republic (Plato)|Plato's ''Republic'']] that are required for all governments. These include a belief that the state's land belongs to it even though it was likely acquired illegitimately and that citizenship is rooted in something more than the accidents of birth. Seymour Hersh also claims that Strauss endorsed noble lies: myths used by political leaders seeking to maintain a cohesive society.<ref>[[Seymour Hersh|Seymour M. Hersh]], [http://www.newyorker.com/fact/content/?030512fa_fact "Selective Intelligence"], ''[[The New Yorker]]'', May 12, 2003, accessed June 1, 2007.{{Dead link|date=January 2017}}</ref><ref name="reason">Brian Doherty, [http://www.reason.com/9707/fe.bailey.shtml "Origin of the Specious: Why Do Neoconservatives Doubt Darwin?"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725170209/http://www.reason.com/9707/fe.bailey.shtml |date=2008-07-25 }}, ''[[Reason Online]]'', July 1997, accessed February 16, 2007.</ref> In ''[[The Power of Nightmares]]'', documentary filmmaker [[Adam Curtis]] opines that "Strauss believed it was for politicians to assert powerful and inspiring myths that everyone could believe in. They might not be true, but they were necessary illusions. One of these was religion; the other was the myth of the nation."<ref>''The Rise of the Politics of Fear''; Episode 1: "Baby It's Cold Outside"</ref>
===Desmond Lee===
{{main article|Desmond Lee}} "Plato has been criticized for his Foundation Myth as if it were a calculated lie. That is partly because the phrase here translated 'magnificent myth' (p.414b) has been conventionally mistranslated 'noble lie'; and this has been used to support the charge that Plato countenances manipulation by propaganda. But the myth is accepted by all three classes, Guardians included. It is meant to replace the national traditions which any community has, which are intended to express the kind of community it is, or wishes to be, its ideals, rather than to state matters of fact."<ref name="Plato p177">Plato: The Republic, Penguin Classics, translated by Desmond Lee, p177</ref>
===Sea of Faith===
{{main article|Sea of Faith}} The Sea of Faith Network (SoF) aims are "Exploring and promoting religious faith as a human creation..."<ref>[http://www.sofn.org.uk/ Sea of Faith homepage]</ref>
Although arguably not an organisation ''based'' on the noble lie, many of their members no longer believe, but continue to espouse religious beliefs for positive social control and continue to hold positions in many religious organizations and various church groups.
==Pious fiction==
===Examples===
====Religious context==== [[File:The Hill Cumorah by C.C.A. Christensen.jpeg|325px|right|thumb|A depiction of [[Joseph Smith]]'s description of receiving the golden plates from the [[angel Moroni]] at the Hill Cumorah]] * [[historical method|Mainstream historical interpretations]] of the [[Hebrew Bible]] (i.e. the [[Tanakh]] or the [[Protestant]] [[Old Testament]]) often consider much of the Tanakh/Jewish Bible to be a pious fiction, such as the conquests of Joshua,<ref>Borras, Judit, ''Jewish Studies at the Turn of the Twentieth Century'', BRILL, 1999, p 117: ".. the overwhelming consensus of modern scholarship is that the conquest tradition of [[Book of Joshua|Joshua]] is a pious fiction composed by the deuteronomistic school …"</ref> and the histories of the [[Pentateuch]].<ref>https://peteenns.com/briefly-3-edgy-things-old-testament-works/</ref><ref>https://peteenns.com/3-things-i-would-like-to-see-evangelical-leaders-stop-saying-about-biblical-scholarship/</ref><ref>Stanley, Christopher, The Hebrew Bible: A Comparative Approach'', Fortress Press, 2009, p 123: "Minimalists begin with the fact that the [[Hebrew Bible]] did not reach its present form until well after the [[Babylonian exile]] … most the that the story was formulated by a group of elites who wanted to justify their claims to dominate … In other words, the narrative [of the Hebrew Bible] is a pious fiction that bears little relation to the actual history of Palestine during the period it purports to narrate."</ref> The [[Book of Daniel]] has also been described as a pious fiction, with the purpose of providing encouragement to Jews.<ref>Carson, D. A. For the Love of God: A Daily Companion for Discovering the Riches of God's Word'', Good News Publishers, 2006, p 19: "Many critics doubt that the account of [[The Book of Daniel|Daniel 4]] is anything more than pious fiction to encourage the Jews."</ref> * Mainstream historical-critical approaches often views stories in the New Testament such as [[Nativity of Jesus|the Virgin Birth]], [[the Visit of the Magi to Jesus]], and others, as pious fictions.<ref>{{Cite book|title=New Testament in the Twentieth Century|last=Jones|first=Maurice|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=63}}</ref> *The [[Book of Mormon]], one of the [[Standard Works]] of the [[Latter Day Saint Movement]], has been described as a [[hoax]] or pious fiction, and it is not accepted as containing [[divine revelation]] by those outside the Latter Day Saint movement.<ref>Skousen, Royal, ''The Book of Mormon: the earliest text'', Yale University Press, 2009, p x: "Outsiders generally consider this book [the Book of Mormon] a nineteenth-century hoax or pious fiction …"</ref> * The [[Quran]], the sacred text of [[Islam]], has been described as a pious fiction by several authors.<ref>{{cite book|last=Berkey|first=Jonathan P.|title=The formation of Islam : religion and society in the Near East, 600-1800|year=2008|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York|isbn=978-0-521-58813-3|page=286|edition=[Online-Ausg.]}}</ref><ref name="Crone and Cook 1980 277">{{cite book|last=Crone and Cook|first=Patricia and Michael|title=Hagarism: the Making of the Islamic World|year=1980|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge, UK|isbn=978-0-521-29754-7|pages=277}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Luxenberg|first=Christoph|title=The Syro-Aramaic Reading of the Koran: a Contribution to the Decoding of the Language of the Koran|year=2007 (English edition)|publisher=Verlag Hans Schiler|isbn=978-3-89930-088-8|pages=349}}</ref> The [[hadith]], likewise, have been described as a collection of various pious fictions by several authors.<ref name="Crone and Cook 1980 277"/><ref>{{cite book|last=Brown|first=Jonathan|title=The Canonization of al-Bukhari and Muslim: the Formation and Function of the Sunni Hadith Canon|year=2011|publisher=Brill Academic Publishers|isbn=978-90-04-21152-0|pages=431}}</ref> * Dale Eickelman writes that [[Muslim]] [[fuqaha|jurists]] employ a pious fiction when they assert that [[Shariah|Islamic law]] is invariant, when in fact it is subject to change.<ref>Eickelman, Dale, ''Muslim politics'', Princeton University Press, 2004, p 26: "Emendations and additions to purportedly invariant and complete Islamic law (sharia) have occurred throughout Islamic history…. Muslim jurists have rigorously maintained the pious fiction that there can be no change in divinely revealed law, even as they have exercised their independent judgment (ijtihad) to create a kind of de facto legislation."</ref> * The relationship between the modern celebration of [[Christmas]] and the [[historical Jesus|historical]] [[Nativity of Jesus|birth of Jesus]] has also been described as such.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kJIhXqNwIIUC&lpg=PA476&dq=christmas%20pious%20fiction&pg=PA476#v=onepage&q=christmas%20pious%20fiction&f=false |title=Scripting Jesus: The Gospels in Rewrite - L. Michael White - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Top 20 football chants |url=http://www.independent.ie/unsorted/features/how-december-25-became-christmas-day-65604.html |title=How December 25 became Christmas Day... - Features, Unsorted |publisher=Independent.ie |date= 2006-12-21|accessdate=2011-09-27}}</ref><ref>http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/columnists/guest_contributors/article405481.ece{{dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref>
====Other contexts==== *Fredrick Pike describes some morale-boosting efforts during the [[Great Depression]] as pious fictions.<ref>Pike, Fredrick, ''FDR's Good Neighbor Policy: sixty years of generally gentle chaos'', University of Texas Press, 1995, p 79: :"In the Depression era, a great many Americans, north and south of the border, succumbed to the pious fiction that underlay the Krausist-Areilist-Marxist nonmaterial rewards aspect of good neighborliness… Without the occasional seasoning of pious fictions, concocted by intellectuals who in their delusions of grandeur try to introduce elements of dream live into crude reality, might not the real world be a far more vicious jungle than it is?"</ref>

{{for|the shopping center in Houston|Palm Center (Houston)}} The '''Palm Center''' is a [[think tank]] founded in 1998 at the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]], that produces scholarship designed to improve the quality of public dialogue about critical and controversial [[public policy]] issues. It commissions and disseminates research in the areas of gender, sexuality, and the military that has been published in leading social scientific journals and cited in the press. The Palm Center is a resource for university-affiliated as well as independent scholars, students, journalists, opinion leaders, and members of the public.
At its founding in 1998, it was known as the Center for the Study of [[Sexual minorities|Sexual Minorities]] in the Military. It was renamed in 2006 in recognition of a one million dollar endowment gift from the Michael D. Palm Foundation.<ref>''Chronoicle of Philanthropy'': [http://philanthropy.com/article/Philanthropys-Military/128431/ Anthony Bowen and Andrew Lane, "End of “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell” Is a Victory for Philanthropy," July 26, 2011], accessed February 1, 2012</ref>
The Palm Center's research has been cited on the floor of Congress and covered by newspapers and radio and television stations throughout the world. Palm scholars have delivered briefings and lectures at the [[British Ministry of Defence]], the [[United States Military Academy]] at West Point, the [[United States Naval Academy]], the [[United States Air Force Academy]], the [[United States Army War College|Army War College]] and the [[National Defense University]].
The director of the Palm Center is [[Aaron Belkin]].<ref>''New York Times'': [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/26/us/26bcjames.html Scott James, "Celebration of Gay Pride Masks Community in Transition," June 25, 2011], accessed February 1, 2012</ref>

'''''The Periodic Table of Videos''''' (usually shortened to '''''Periodic Videos''''') is a series of videos about [[chemical elements]] and the [[periodic table]]. They are published on [[YouTube]] and produced by [[Brady Haran]], a former [[BBC]] video journalist, featuring Sir [[Martyn Poliakoff]] ("The Professor"), Peter Licence, [[Stephen Liddle]], Debbie Kays, Neil Barnes, Sam Tang and others at the [[University of Nottingham]].<ref name="arstechnica">{{cite web |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/news/2008/07/periodic-table-brought-to-life.ars |title=Periodic Table brought to life |author=Jonathan M. Gitlin |date=July 16, 2008|publisher=[[Ars Technica]] |accessdate=17 July 2010}}</ref>
==Development== The project began recording on 9 June 2008 and the initial videos were completed on 17 July 2008.<ref name="professor1" /> The collection includes videos, each just a few minutes long, for all 118 known elements with a video for each element, as well as many additional supplemental chemistry videos. The 118 element videos and introduction videos were all shot unscripted in June and July 2008.<ref name="acs08" />
Since the initial videos were completed in 2008 the team has been refining and uploading revised versions of the videos with new video and in higher resolutions.<ref name="acs08" /> A key example of this revising is with the [[xenon]] video that was redone in honour of professor [[Neil Bartlett (chemist)|Neil Bartlett]] who died on 5 August 2008;<ref name="acs08" /> Bartlett prepared one of the first xenon compounds, [[xenon hexafluoroplatinate]].<ref name="acs08" />
==Content== Poliakoff is the most visible presenter on the videos and his hair, reminiscent of [[Einstein]] or a [[mad scientist]], is frequently commented upon in the videos.<ref name="acs08">{{Cite journal|author=[http://pubs.acs.org/cen/staff/biosr.html Ritter, Stephen]|title = Elements Achieve Internet Stardom|journal = [[Chemical & Engineering News]]|volume = 86|issue = 37|pages = 42–43|publisher = [[American Chemical Society]]|date = September 15, 2008|url = http://pubs.acs.org/cen/education/86/8637education.html|accessdate = July 17, 2010}}</ref> The combination of the professor's hair and amusing experiments has made these videos quite popular.<ref name="acs08"/> Although uncertain what to think about the attention given to his hair, Professor Poliakoff is excited with the success of the videos, stating "With a few hours of work, I have lectured to more students than I have reached in my entire career."<ref name="acs08"/> The YouTube channel as of December 2017, has over 1 million subscribers and the videos have surpassed 170 million views.<ref name="professor1">{{Cite video|people = Brady Haran (producer)|title = The Professor talks about The Periodic Table of Videos|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6yT8kvHlgeg|publisher = The Periodic Table of Videos|location = Nottingham, UK|date = 31 May 2010|accessdate = 17 July 2010}}</ref><ref name="YouTube">{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/periodicvideos |title=Periodic Table of Videos Channel |author= |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=17 July 2010}}</ref> The YouTube channel is now one of the most popular chemistry related channels on all of YouTube.<ref name="EPSRCvideo"/> The producers of the videos have received praise from Nobel Laureates, chemistry professors, and the general public, says Professor Poliakoff.<ref name="acs08"/> Chemistry Nobel Laureate [[Roald Hoffmann]] has even offered his praise of the videos, stating they "are like the best reality show I've ever seen – the universe revealing itself, element by element."<ref name="acs08"/>
The videos feature various experiments and demonstrations of the elements, some too dangerous to be performed in a classroom.<ref name="acs08"/><ref name="BBC1">{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/sci/tech/7507986.stm |title=Elements brought to life online |author=Staff |date=15 July 2008 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=17 July 2010}}</ref> Though the presenters take appropriate precautions when doing such experiments and provide adequate warnings, some scientists have criticized the dangerous experiments fearing people might try them at home and get hurt.<ref name="acs08"/> The intent of the videos is to bring chemistry to a new generation of students and to get them enthused about science and understand how chemists think and what chemists are trying to do.<ref name="cbs"/><ref name="telegraph1">{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/science-news/3347317/YouTube-periodic-table-Explosive-video-guides.html |title=YouTube periodic table: Explosive video guides |author=Matthew Moore |date=15 Jul 2008 |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=17 July 2010}}</ref> Many school teachers now incorporate these videos into their classes,<ref name="professor1"/><ref name="cbs">{{cite video|date = 20 December 2009|title = Web Wizard|url = http://www.cbsnews.com/video/watch/?id=6002511n|publisher = [[CBS News]]|accessdate = 17 July 2010}}</ref> and the professor has even recorded video responses to some of the students' questions.<ref>{{Cite video|people = Brady Haran (producer)|title = Questions for The Professor – ''Periodic Table of Videos''|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0F_ztEv_v1Y|publisher = The Periodic Table of Videos|location = Nottingham, UK|date = 3 August 2009|accessdate = 7 July 2010}}</ref> Some of the most popular videos are those of [[sodium]],<ref name="telegraph1"/> [[potassium]], and [[uranium]].
''The Periodic Table of Videos'' team has had two live performances to date, the first in May 2009 at the [[Broadway Media Centre]] in [[Nottingham]], and most recently in July 2010 at the [[EuroScience]] Open Forum (ESOF) in [[Turin]], Italy.<ref name="professor1"/>
==Financing== A grant from the [[Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council]] of £25,249 was awarded on 19 January, 2010 to extend the video library to include topical videos on molecules of general interest.<ref name="EPSRCvideo">{{cite video|date = June 4, 2010|title = It's elementary, my dear Poliakoff!|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-EmN6XpbIBI|publisher = [[Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council]]|accessdate = 17 July 2010}}</ref><ref name="grant">{{cite web |url=http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/ViewGrant.aspx?GrantRef=EP/H027424/1 |title=''The Periodic Table of Videos'': MolVids Grant |publisher=[[Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council]] |accessdate=July 17, 2010}}</ref> The first of these new videos were on [[carbon dioxide]] and [[methane]].<ref name="EPSRCvideo"/>
==Videos== ''The Periodic Table of Videos'' has filmed at least one video for each of the 118 elements (from [[hydrogen]] to [[oganesson]]).<ref>[http://www.periodicvideos.com/ Read below the periodic table] "Tables charting the chemical elements have been around since the 19th century – but this modern version has a short video about each one. We've done all 118 – but our job's not finished. Now we're updating all the videos with new stories, better samples and bigger experiments.
Plus we're making films about other areas of chemistry, latest news and occasional adventures away from the lab.
We've also started a new series – The Molecular Videos – featuring our favourite molecules and compounds.
All these videos are created by video journalist Brady Haran, featuring real working chemists from the University of Nottingham."</ref> They have also filmed several videos that discuss molecules such as D<sub>2</sub>O ([[heavy water]])<ref>[http://www.periodicvideos.com/videos/mv_heavywater.htm Heavy water video]</ref> and [[sulfuric acid]].<ref>[http://www.periodicvideos.com/videos/mv_sulfuric_acid.htm Sulfuric acid video]</ref> Also filmed are "Chem definitions" that provide an explanation to words that are used in chemistry. Lastly, the team has filmed "Roadtrips" where they travel to different places in the world that have an importance in chemistry (such as the mine outside [[Ytterby]], [[Sweden]], which had four elements – [[yttrium]], [[terbium]], [[erbium]], and [[ytterbium]] – named after it.)
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * {{cite journal|last1=Haran|first1=Brady|last2=Poliakoff|first2=Martyn|title=How to measure the impact of chemistry on the small screen|journal=Nature Chemistry|date=21 February 2011|issue=3|pages=180–82|doi=10.1038/nchem.990|url=http://www.nature.com/nchem/journal/v3/n3/full/nchem.990.html|volume=3|pmid=21336314|bibcode=2011NatCh...3..180H}} {{Subscription}} * {{cite journal|last1=Haran|first1=Brady|last2=Poliakoff|first2=Martyn|title=The Periodic Table of Videos|journal=Science|date=27 May 2011|volume=332|issue=6033|pages=1046–47|doi=10.1126/science.1196980|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/332/6033/1046|pmid=21617067|bibcode=2011Sci...332.1046H}}
